title: Identifying Disneyland nametag font
content:
I'm looking to identify the font that is used for the names on the Disneyland nametags. Any help is greatly appreciated!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140307124417im_/http:/typophile.com/files/dlyaomd_6003.jpg)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140307124417im_/http:/typophile.com/files/logo_phpBB_6329.gif)
author: BruinChiq

comments.content: This is not really a "font" per se. There are machines for engraving letters in metal using a cutting tool. This looks typical of that method. They don't use "fonts" in the normal sense, instead tracing paths in the shape of letters. [Here is an example of what I mean.](http://web.archive.org/web/20140307124417/http:/www.suregrave.com/wizzard-st.html) Originally, before they worked with computers, you would actually trace a sort of template with letters cut into it with a sort of pantographic mechanism. I remember seeing one of these when I was a kid. I believe the letter shapes go back to those older machines.

Arial Rounded (shudder) is close to "NAMETAGMUSEUM" but Mark is right about the engraving machine.

- Lex

These are from the same engraving gadgets you see them use in the malls to make your custom license plate frames and desk nameplates. The [Leroy Lettering Guides](http://web.archive.org/web/20140307124417/http:/www.tpub.com/engbas/3-35.htm) worked on a similar principle -- you trace the letter shapes that are engraved into a template and the pen (or engraving tool) at the end of the pantographic device reproduces the letter shape.

- Mike Yanega
